parameters: Let's learn some Japanese vocabulary!
To give you a break from learning Hiragana every
lesson, we will mix it up and learn vocabulary every
now and then. We'll cover 10 new words each lesson.
As we go, we will demonstrate how to read and pronounce
each word. You'll see how to write each word in
Hiragana, based on the Hiragana we know so far.
I'll show you our first word and demonstrate how these
vocabulary lessons work.
vocab-hai
Let's break down the text above! The first line, in
blue, is how to write the Japanese word in Romaji.
Romaji is a system designed to transcribe Japanese
sounds using the English alphabet.
Romaji is very common, and there's a good chance you've
come across it before. Words that are borrowed from
Japanese use Romaji - think of words like tsunami,
karaoke, sensei, etc.
Romaji is super simple and easy to read. As you learn
more Hiragana, and gain an understanding of the
syllables used in Japanese, you'll be able to write
words in Romaji as well as Hiragana.
For the vocabulary we are learning, you can use the
Romaji reading until we learn all of the relevant
Hiragana. Which brings me to the next line, written
in black.
This is the Hiragana reading of the word. As lessons
get more advanced, and you learn more Hiragana, these
words will become entirely written in Hiragana.
When there are syllables used that we haven't learned
yet, I'll just display the Romaji. So, in our example
above, you'll see it as 'ha-い'. We haven't learned
the Hiragana for 'ha' yet, but we've learned 'い'!
The dashes in between are just to symbolise the gap
between each syllable. You don't need to actually
write these in Hiragana or Romaji.
And finally, our third line in orange is the English
translation of the word. So, the example above teaches
us that the Japanese word 'hai' means 'yes' in English.
Awesome!
Next, I'll discuss how to pronounce it properly.
This word sounds like "hi" or "high". However, remember
how い sounds like "ee"? The word 'hai' is actually
pronounced "ha-ee", but since Japanese is a language
spoken at a rapid pace, the syllables tend to merge.
A general rule of thumb when speaking Japanese is that
the sounds of syllables do not change, regardless of
what syllable they follow or precede.
We all know that English words can change pronunciation
in strange ways, and may not even be pronounced as they
are written.
However, in Japanese, every syllable has a specific
pronunciation and it's the same in every word it
appears in. There are a couple of little exceptions,
but nothing to be concerned with at this stage.
Would you like to listen to the pronunciation of
'hai' again?
Hear pronunciation again
Continue lesson
Hear pronunciation again
Continue lesson
Let's look at our second word!
vocab-iie
This is 'iie', which means 'no'. This is an interesting
word because it's made up only of vowels.
When dealing with repeated vowels, such as いい, you
draw out the length of the sound. It's not quite the
same as repeating the vowel twice. Listen carefully
to the example pronunciation.
Would you like to listen to the pronunciation again?
Hear pronunciation again
Continue lesson
Hear pronunciation again
Continue lesson
Let's look at our next word!
vocab-watashi
'Watashi' is the Japanese word for 'I', used when
referring to yourself. It's not a substitute for the
letter 'i'.
You'll use 'watashi' often in conversation when
talking about yourself. It's a formal and polite word.
There are other more casual words used to refer to
yourself in Japanese, but they are saved for chatting
with your friends and family.
Would you like to listen to the pronunciation again?
Hear pronunciation again
Continue lesson
Hear pronunciation again
Continue lesson
Ready for word 4?
vocab-anata
'Anata' is the Japanese word for 'you', used when
referring to the person you are talking to.
You can use this word in conversation when
talking about your conversation partner.
However, it can be considered rude to use it in the
wrong context. Most of the time you refer to people
by their name, even when talking directly to them. It
sounds weird in English, but it's normal in Japanese.
Would you like to listen to the pronunciation again?
Hear pronunciation again
Continue lesson
Hear pronunciation again
Continue lesson
Ready for word 5? The rest of the words in this lesson
are for objects used when studying. Look around now -
hopefully you have most of these things handy!
vocab-pen
'Pen' is the Japanese word for 'pen'. Who knew??? This
is a word that has been borrowed from English.
It's an easy word, and it's even pronounced the same!
When you write words borrowed from other languages in
Japanese, you wouldn't normally use Hiragana. Instead,
you'd use a set of characters called Katakana, which
are specifically for foreign words.
However, since this software is about learning
Hiragana, we will write borrowed words like
'pen' in Hiragana and Romaji.
Would you like to listen to the pronunciation again?
Hear pronunciation again
Continue lesson
Hear pronunciation again
Continue lesson
Ready for word 6?
vocab-enpitsu
'Enpitsu' is Japanese for 'pencil'.
It's a bit of a mouthful, so listen to the
pronunciation a few times and practice saying it
slowly.
Would you like to listen to the pronunciation again?
Hear pronunciation again
Continue lesson
Hear pronunciation again
Continue lesson
Ready for word 7?
vocab-tsukue
'Tsukue' is Japanese for 'desk'.
Would you like to listen to the pronunciation again?
Hear pronunciation again
Continue lesson
Hear pronunciation again
Continue lesson
Ready for word 8?
vocab-isu
'Isu' is Japanese for 'chair'.
Would you like to listen to the pronunciation again?
Hear pronunciation again
Continue lesson
Hear pronunciation again
Continue lesson
Ready for word 9?
vocab-hon
'Hon' is Japanese for 'book'.
Would you like to listen to the pronunciation again?
Hear pronunciation again
Continue lesson
Hear pronunciation again
Continue lesson
Ready for word 10?
vocab-noto
'Noto' is Japanese for 'notebook'.
Would you like to listen to the pronunciation again?
Hear pronunciation again
Continue lesson
Hear pronunciation again
Continue lesson
That's the end of our first vocabulary lesson! You
now know 10 Japanese words that are going to be very
useful. Well done!
We're going to move on to the next Hiragana lesson.
Before we do, would you like to save your progress
so far?
Yes
No
Yes
No
A
